Award.AwardTitle: New enzyme-catalyzed reactions from catalytically promiscuous ancestral enzymes
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry and the Biotechnology, Biochemical, and Biomass Engineering Program in the Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems Division, Drs. Romas Kazlauskas and Antony Dean, from the University of Minnesota, Twin Cities, will resurrect ancestral generalist enzymes using gene synthesis. The targets are ancestors of hydroxynitrile lyases, which catalyze a carbon-carbon bond formation: addition of cyanide to aldehydes. The research will test the ability of these ancestral enzymes to catalyze other carbon-carbon bond forming reactions and optimize them for different reactions. A current challenge in chemical synthesis is to assemble complex molecules catalytically, and stereoselectively while using environmentally friendly conditions and reagents. Biocatalysis is a potential solution, but the reaction range of current biocatalysts is limited. This work constitutes a new approach to discover biocatalysts that catalyze unnatural reactions, which uses carbon-carbon bond forming reactions as a test case.

Studies of resurrected ancestral enzymes seek to answer basic questions of how new enzymes and metabolic pathways evolve. In addition, resurrected ancestral enzymes may be starting points for engineering new enzymes because ancestral enzymes can catalyze additional chemical reactions, including potentially useful unnatural reactions. The proposed work will train under-graduate, graduate and postdoctoral students in a chemical approach to solving interdisciplinary problems, actively recruit and include students from groups underrepresented in chemical sci-ences, and support outreach to elementary school students.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
Enzymes are the molecular machines of biology. They digest our food, build our bodies and create our memories. Chemists seek to also extend enzymes to industrial use. These molecular machines could make pharmaceuticals, chemicals and materials and thus replace  replace complex, dangerous syntheses. In some cases, this replacement has succeeded, but unfortunately, nature's enzymes often cannot catalyze the needed reactions. One place to search for these reactions is as accidental reactions, called catalytic promiscuity. But it is inefficient to search for accidental reactions willy nilly. Researchers hypothesize that ancestral enzymes from millions of years ago may have been promiscuous. If true, this would be a great place to search for promiscuous enzymes. 

In this project we reconstructed 10 ancestral enzymes from about 100 million years ago. This reconstruction starts will modern enzymes, constructs a family tree and makes best guesses about the ancestors at each point in the tree. As an analogy, comparison of me and my brother allows one to guess characteristics of our father; including my cousins in this comparison allows guessing about our grandfather. By including more relatives, one can make guesses further back in time. 

We measured the ability of these ancestral enzymes to catalyze accidental reactions and indeed found that they catalyzed more accidental reactions than their modern descendants. Thus, ancestral enzymes are a good place to search for accidental catalytic activities that can be useful to chemists to make complex molecules. Some ancestral enzymes showed greater abilities than others. The intellectual merit of this work is a better understanding of how enzymes evolved and the knowledge that potentially useful accidental activities can be found in ancestral enzymes. A remaining question is what makes these ancestral enzyme different. Preliminary work suggest that the important differences lie throughout the protein, not just at the reaction site. 

The broader impacts of this support were training of students and community outreach. The PI provided research opportunities and training for fourteen undergraduate researchers, two high school students, four graduate students and three postdoctoral fellows as part of this support. The PI hosted nine international visiting researchers. The PI and students participated in community outreach at at Spark-Y Youth Action Labs in Minneapolis and the Science Museum of Minnesota.

 


Last Modified: 11/03/2015
Modified by: Romas J Kazlauskas
